Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Situation2: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today.
Story: The clock on my desk blinked 4:00 PM, and my heart thudded in my chest. Only an hour left in my shift, and I was still three sales short of my weekly target. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “We need you to hit your numbers this week.” I stared at the list of cold leads, my fingers hovering over the phone. If I stayed and pushed through, maybe I could make those last sales. But at the same time, my Buddhist group was gathering for our weekly meditation—an hour of stillness and mindfulness that I cherished, a time to let go of striving and simply be. I could almost hear the gentle chime of the singing bowl, feel the calm settling over me. Yet here I was, torn between the pressure to perform and the call to inner peace. My breath caught, shallow and uneasy, as I weighed the demands of my job against the teachings I tried so hard to live by. The phone felt heavy in my hand, and I closed my eyes, caught in the tension between ambition and acceptance, between the world’s expectations and my own longing for tranquility.
